awd_titl_txt: CNH-L: Coastal Processes and Human Response to Shoreline Change
awd_abstract_narration:
A non-technical description of the project that eplains the significance and importance

Coastlines are influenced by a complex set of physical processes. In addition, human response to coastal change is a result of complicated and often interlocking decisions. This project will develop a set of integrated models to better understand the dynamics of developed shoreline evolution under different geologic settings, climatological variables such as wave and storm influence, development scenarios, legal and regulatory regimes, and strategies for coastal protection or response. The models of the long-term dynamic interactions between development and coastal processes will be useful to project how developed coastlines may respond to future alterations due to sea-level rise, erosion, and inundation that are caused by changing climate conditions. Two examples from Massachusetts and the New Jersey coasts are selected as test cases since both have long histories of development and attempts at coastal protection that span different geologic and storm climate settings. The project will develop an ongoing short course that will inform coastal land managers of the major findings and applications.

A technical description of the project

This project will yield new tools and information to improve knowledge of the alongshore-coupled interactions among the geological framework, geomorphic processes, the economics of human shoreline protection measures, and how developed shoreline dynamics may change due to climate-driven exogenous effects, such as sea-level rise. Model results will be integrated within a realistic policy framework to offer guidance on economically efficient and sustainable ways to manage coastline resources at the scale of the littoral cell. The work will advance the state of the art in morphodynamic models of coastal evolution in response to climate change effects and the integration of geologic models with those of economic consequences and human behavior. The multi-disciplinary project team includes geomorphologists, policy and economic scientists, and legal experts who have an established history of successful collaboration
with integrated geo-economic models of coastal evolution involving human interventions.

por.por_cntn:
The primary goal of this project was to develop a set of integrated geological and socio-economic models to better understand the dynamics of developed shorelines under different geologic settings, climatologic forcing (wave and storm influence), development scenarios, legal/regulatory regimes, and protection (or response) strategies, over timescales of decades to a century. Focusing on the littoral cell?the alongshore-connected series of geologic environments from upcoast sediment sources (headlands and bluffs) to downdrift coastal stretches, this research helps us better understand how to manage coastal change hazards, with a focus on the bi-directional interactions between the natural processes that sculpt the shore and local human responses to shoreline change.

Intellectual Merit: This research developed, applied, and tested geoeconomics models, focusing on: barrier island evolution, cost models of artificial dune construction, coupled alongshore feedbacks for both soft (beach nourishment) and hard (shore-perpendicular rock walls) interventions, and the effect of risk-adversity on long-term nourishment decisions.
- Using a morphodynamic model of barrier evolution, this research quantified circumstances under which episodic (or periodic) barrier retreat might happen spontaneously, even under constant forcing, helping interpretation of barrier deposits and helping predict threshold barrier behaviors, particularly when barriers face sea-level acceleration.
- A coupled alongshore model studied how barrier overwash interacts with neighboring coastal regions, affecting barrier evolution and long-term stability. Models demonstrate how prevention of overwash by development affects neighboring communities, feeding back into respective nourishment decisions.
- A model of constructed dune morphodynamics and human activities was used to derive mathematical expressions for optimal berm and dune size as a function of geologic and economic parameters, including nourishment costs and baseline property value. Model results show how subsidies play a role in the affordability of large dunes depending on community property values.
- A geo-economic model explored the impacts of shore-perpendicular rock walls and beach nourishment practices on coastal evolution and management. Applied along the New Jersey and New York coasts, the model quantitatively analyzes the difference between coordinated and uncoordinated strategies between alongshore communities, as well as when abandonment of properties is economically justified.
- Compiling new data, HPM?s (economic ?Hedonic Pricing Models?) were developed for Scituate, MA and six municipalities on Long Beach Island, NJ. The former case involves estimating the risks comprising an aging seawall infrastructure. The latter involves a case of understanding the net benefits of a large-scale constructed dune system.
- Applying a theoretical geo-economic approach, we examined key factors affecting decisions about the choice of beach width when eroded coastal beaches are being nourished (i.e., when fill is placed to widen a beach). Risk aversion can affect a coastal property owner's choice of beach width in contradictory ways: the expected benefits of hazard protection must be balanced against the expected costs of repeated nourishment actions.

Broader Impacts: This project included direct participation of more than 8 graduate and 5 undergraduate students, including training in the interdisciplinary aspects of coupled human-nature systems. As an example of the benefit of the combination of policy and physical science training, former PhD students went on to become a NOAA Knauss Fellow a fellow at the Rutgers University Eagleton Institute of Politics. The project included numerous public presentations to coastal communities in Massachusetts and New Jersey, with the PI also contributing as a member of the Town of Falmouth Coastal Resilience Committee. For both Massachusetts and New Jersey, the research also searched through regulations, executive orders, state agency plans and reports for explicit references to sediment transport concepts including to assess existing legal frameworks for managing alongshore-connected properties and communities.
